message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical findings suggest asthma, which is characterized by airway hyperreactivity to external allergens causing intermittent airway obstruction. Option A is characteristic of emphysema, Option B suggests cystic fibrosis, and Option C suggests chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, such as breathlessness and wheezing, suggest an obstructive airway disease. Among the options, only airway hyperreactivity to external allergens causing intermittent airway obstruction fits well with the presentation of the patient. The other options are related to conditions like bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, and emphysema, which are less likely in a 4-year-old child.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest that the child is experiencing asthma, which is caused by airway hyperreactivity to external allergens leading to intermittent airway obstruction. Destruction of elastic layers of bronchial walls leading to abnormal dilation is seen in bronchiectasis. Defective chloride channel function leading to mucus plugging is seen in cystic fibrosis. Inflammation leading to permanent dilation and destruction of alveoli is seen in emphysema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of breathlessness, more prominent during the day when she plays in the garden, suggests intermittent airway obstruction caused by external allergens. This is supported by the presence of intercostal retractions and a slight expiratory wheeze on auscultation. Option A refers to bronchiectasis, option B refers to cystic fibrosis, and option C refers to emphysema, none of which fit this patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings suggest the child has asthma, which is characterized by airway hyperreactivity to external allergens causing intermittent airway obstruction. Option A describes bronchiectasis, option B describes cystic fibrosis, and option C describes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which are all different from asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The child’s symptoms suggest asthma, which is characterized by airway hyperreactivity to external allergens causing intermittent airway obstruction. Option A describes bronchiectasis, while Option C describes emphysema, which are not likely in a 4-year-old patient. Option B describes cystic fibrosis, which typically presents with recurrent respiratory infections and poor growth rather than sudden onset breathlessness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical findings suggest that the child has asthma, which is characterized by airway hyperreactivity to external allergens causing intermittent airway obstruction. Other options such as destruction of the elastic layers of bronchial walls (emphysema), defective chloride channel function (cystic fibrosis), and inflammation leading to permanent dilation and destruction of alveoli (bronchiectasis) are not consistent with the presented history and physical examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of breathlessness, wheezing, and intercostal retractions suggest asthma, which is characterized by airway hyperreactivity and intermittent airway obstruction in response to external allergens. Option A is characteristic of bronchiectasis, option B is characteristic of cystic fibrosis, and option C is characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest asthma, which is characterized by airway hyperreactivity to external allergens. Option A describes the mechanism of bronchiectasis, option B describes the mechanism of cystic fibrosis, and option C describes the mechanism of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). None of these options match the patient’s symptoms.

The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest that the child has asthma, which is characterized by airway hyperreactivity and intermittent airway obstruction in response to external allergens. Option A describes bronchiectasis, option B describes cystic fibrosis, and option C describes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which are all different conditions than asthma.
